question: Elaine!
answer: Ted!

question: I came home early and found your note. I guess you meant for me to read it later. Elaine, I've got to talk to you.
answer: I just don't want to go over it any more.

question: I know things haven't been right for a long time, but it'll be different. If you'll just be patient, I can work things out.
answer: I have been patient and I've tried to help, but you wouldn't even let me do that.

question: Don't you feel anything for me at all any more?
answer: It takes so many things to make love last. Most of all it takes respect. And I can't live with a man I don't respect!

question: Look, you'll be back in town tomorrow night. We'll have dinner -- talk it over.
answer: I won't be back. I've requested the Atlanta run.

question: Elaine, not yet. I promise you I really can change.
answer: Then why don't you take the job that Louie Netz offered you at Boeing?

question: You know I haven't been able to get near an airplane since the war. And even if I could, they wouldn't hire me because of my war record.
answer: Your war record? You're the only one keeping that alive. For everyone else it's ancient history.

question: You expect me to believe that?
answer: It's the truth. What's hurt you the most is your record since the war. Different cities, different jobs, and not one of them shows you can accept any real responsibility.

question: But if you'll just give me...
answer: It's too late, Ted. When I get back to Chicago, I'm going to start my life all over again. I'm sorry.

question: Any word on that storm lifting over Salt Lake, Clarence?
answer: Unlikely, Victor. I just reviewed the Area Report for 1609 hours through 2400 hours. That's an occluded front stalled over the Dakotas -- backed up all the way to Utah.

question: If it decides to push over into the Great Lakes it could get plenty soupy. How about the southern route, around Tulsa?
answer: I double checked the terminal forecast and winds aloft. IFR ceilings all the way.

question: Where do they top out?
answer: Well, there's some light scattered cover at twenty thousand with icing around eighteen.

question: Looks like the original flight plan over Denver is still the best bet.
answer: Denver it is.

question: Thank you.
answer: Nervous?

question: Yes.
answer: First time?

question: DRAMATIC MUSIC. Engines one and two REV UP.
answer: Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing.

question: ENGINES three and four REV UP.
answer: Murdock and Oveur look toward right wing.

question: Two more ENGINES REV UP.
answer: Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing and do a double take.

question: Two more ENGINES REV UP.
answer: Murdock and Oveur are confused and counting on their fingers.

question: Good-bye, darling.
answer: Oh, good-bye, Bill! Have your picture taken as soon as you get there and send me one!

question: I will.
answer: Don't you go getting fat or anything.

question: Don't worry, I won't. Okay, here -- hurry!
answer: Oh, but it's your watch. You shouldn't. You'll need it.

question: Good-bye, darling.
answer: Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.

question: So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.
answer: Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.

question: Good-bye, darling.
answer: Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.

question: Would you like something to read?
answer: Do you have anything light?

question: How about this leaflet
answer: Yes. Thank you.

question: I happened to be passing, and I thought you might like some corfee.
answer: That's very nice of you. Thank you. Ah, won't you sit down?

question: Thank you. Cream?
answer: No, thank you. I take it black. Like my men.

question: Were you vacationing in Los Angeles?
answer: Well, it really wasn't a vacation. You see, I'm a teacher in the New York City school system, and I was attending a seminar on visual aids to education. Are you from L.A.?

question: Would you like to order dinner now?
answer: When can I see the cockpit, Dad? Aw, gee whiz.

question: I tell you what, Joey. I'll talk to the Captain and see what I can arrange.
answer: Gee! That'd be swell!

question: Oh, Ted, I never knew I could be so happy. These past few months have been wonderful. Tomorrow why don't we drive up the coast to that little seafood place and... What's the matter?
answer: My orders came through. My squadron ships out tomorrow. I'll be leading a very important mission.

question: Oh, Ted, please be careful. I worry about you so much.
answer: I love you, Elaine.

question: Joey, here's something we give our special visitors. Would you like to have it?
answer: Thank you. Thanks a lot!

question: Have you ever been in a cockpit before?
answer: No, sir. I've never been up in a plane before.

question: Flight two-zero-niner to Denver radio. Climbing to cruise at forty-two thousand. Will report again over Lincoln. Over and out.
answer: Wait a minute. I know you. You're Kareem Abdul Jabbar. You play basketball for the Los Angeles Lakers!

question: I'm sorry, son, but you must have me confused with someone else. My name is Roger Murdock. I'm the co-pilot. Ah, Victor, why don't you get the coordinates on the altitude vector and find out the ratio of direct velocity over engine speed?
answer: You are Kareem. I've seen you play. My Dad's got season tickets!

question: All right. But just remember, my name is Roger Murdock. I'm an airline pilot. Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.
answer: I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.

question: Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.
answer: ...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.

question: We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.
answer: ...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.

question: Elaine, just hear me out. I know things haven't been right for a long time. But it will be different...like it was in the beginning. Remember?
answer: I remember everything. All I have are memories. Mostly I remember...the nights when we were together. I remember how you used to hold me...and how I used to sit on your face and wriggle...and then afterwards how we'd watch until the sun came up. When it did, it was almost like...like each new day was created...only for us.

question: That's the way I've always wanted it to be, Elaine.
answer: But it won't be. Not as long as you insist on living in the past! You got a telegram from headquarters today.

question: Headquarters!? What is it?
answer: It's a big building where the generals meet. But that's not important right now. They've cleared you of any blame for what happened on that raid. Isn't that good news?

question: Is it? Because of my mistake six men didn't return from that raid.
answer: Seven. Lieutenant Zipp died this morning. Ted, Doctor Sandler says you'll be out in a week. Isn't that wonderful?

question: I wish I could say the same for George Zipp.
answer: Be patient, Ted. No one expects you to get over this immediately.

question: All right. Take five.
answer: I found a wonderful apartment for us. It's got a brick fireplace and a cute little bedroom with mirrors on the ceiling. And...

question: That's Captain Geline. He thinks he's a pilot, still fighting the war.
answer: What's his problem?

question: Excuse me, Sister?
answer: Yes?

question: There's a little girl on board who's ill and...
answer: Oh yes, I saw. Poor child.

question: Could I borrow your guitar? I thought I might be able to cheer her up.
answer: Of course.

question: Who wants to be first?
answer: Go ahead, Clarence, I got it.

question: How's the weather?
answer: Not so good. We've got some heavy stuff ahead of us. It might get rough again unless we can climb on top. But our airspeed is holding steady at six hundred ten knots.

question: After the war, I just wanted to get as far away from things as possible. So Elaine and I joined the Peace Corps. We were assigned to an isolated tribe, the Molombos.
answer: Also, Supperware products are ideal for storing leftovers to help stretch your food dollar. This two quart "Seals-M-Rite" container with a special "Close-M-Tite" lid keeps hotdog buns fresh for days and prevents sugared cereals from sticking. Meat and dairy products are protected against unwanted refrigerator odors when sealed in this non-slip pastel colored "Freez-o-leer".

question: I think they're getting the hang of it! When we re-enlist I'll teach them baseball!
answer: Ted, I don't want to stay here. It's time for us to go back home -- to the plans we made before the war.

question: Captain, how soon can we land?
answer: I can't tell. No. I mean I'm just not sure.

question: Can't you take a guess?
answer: Well...not for another two hours.

question: You can't take a guess for another two hours?
answer: No, I mean we can't land for another two hours. Fog has closed down everything this side of the mountains. We've got to go through to Chicago!

question: I'll take care of the passengers. Elaine, find out what the two sick people had for dinner. This is Captain Oveur speaking.
answer: Passengers are listening to P.A.

question: Meanwhile, relax and enjoy the rest of your flight. Okay? Okay! That should do it.
answer: Absolute pandemonium. Passengers are yelling, screaming, tearing their hair out, climbing about.

question: Yes?
answer: Oh, Stewardess. My husband is very sick. Can you do something, please?

question: Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing
answer: Yes, of course. We both had fish. Why?

question: Doctor Rumack, Mister Hammen ate fish. And Randy says there are five more cases, and they ate fish, too.
answer: Let's see now. The co-pilot had fish. What did the navigator eat?

question: He had fish, too.
answer: All right, now we know what we're up against. Every passenger on this plane who ate fish for dinner will become violently ill within the next half hour.

question: Just how serious is it, doctor?
answer: Extremely serious. It starts with a slight fever. Then a dryness in the throat. As the virus penetrates the red blood cells the victim becomes dizzy and begins to experience a rash and itching. From there the poison works its way into the central nervous system causing severe muscle spasms, followed by the inevitable drooling. At this point, the entire digestive system is rendered useless, causing the complete collapse of the lower bowels, accompanied by uncontrollable flatulence...until finally the poor bastard is reduced to a quivering, wasted piece of jelly.

question: Hello, I'm Paul Carey from the airline. I'm here to pick up Captain Kramer.
answer: Oh, yes. Come in, Paul. Rex will be right out. Shep, sit...sit! So, I understand you've got a real emergency down there.

question: Well, to tell the truth, they really didn't fill me in on many of the details. Just told me to pick up Captain Kramer.
answer: Something about a plane with no pilot?

question: Yeah, something like that, but as I say, they didn't have time to tell me very much.
answer: Shep, no! I'll bet you have exciting things happen all the time down there.

question: Well...the airline business...does have... its moments... ...but after...awhile...you begin to... ...get used to it.
answer: Shep, no! He gets so excited when new people are here. Are you a pilot yourself?

question: You see, the day we left the village it was raining, so we had to take a special jeep to the main road... In fact, we were lucky to even get a jeep since just the day before the only one we had broke down -- it had a bad axle...
answer: Excuse me, sir. There's been a little problem in the cockpit and I was wondering...

question: The cockpit? What is it?
answer: It's the little room at the front of the plane where the pilots sit. But that's not important right now. The first officer is ill and the Captain would like someone with flying experience to help him with the radio. Do you know anything about planes?

question: Well, I flew in the war, but that was a long time ago. I wouldn't know anything about it.
answer: Would you go up, please?

question: The stewardess said... Both pilots!
answer: Can you fly this airplane and land it?

question: Surely you can't be serious.
answer: I am serious, and don't call me Shirley! What flying experience have you had?

question: Well, I flew single-engine fighters in the Air Force, but this plane has four engines. It's an entirely different kind of flying...all together!!! Besides, I haven't touched any kind of plane in six years.
answer: Mister Striker. I know nothing about flying. All I know is this

question: No, we can't do that; the risk of a flameout is too great. Keep him 24,000. No, feet! One of the passengers is going to land that plane.
answer: Is that possible?

question: Possible, but it's a hundred to one shot. Thousand to one. I know this guy.
answer: You do? Who is it?

question: Yes! The stewardess is here with me! The radio's all yours now. And keep an eye on that number three engine. It's running a little hot.
answer: Rain.

question: And a little ice.
answer: And a little ice!

question: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.
answer: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.

question: It's a damn good thing he doesn't know how much I hate his guts.
answer: It's a damn good thing you don't know how much he hates your guts.

question: After my wife died, I felt like a fifth wheel. You know, so many years being with one person -- a very wonderful person -- makes you always think of yourself as part of a pair...When Ethel passed away, I was lost. I couldn't function socially and I couldn't function in business.
answer: Well, after a thing like that you wouldn't be expected to.

question: But I think it's time we stopped talking about me. A woman like you -- why haven't you ever married?
answer: Well, I'm afraid that's a question that's all too easy to answer.

question: I know the answer -- Career. A smart woman like you became so involved in your work, you didn't have time for marriage.
answer: I wish I could fool myself into believing that that's the reason. The truth of the matter is, nobody ever asked me.

question: You know, here we are having coffee together, and discussing education and business and economy...and we don't even know each other's names...full names I mean.
answer: Mine's Eleanor. Eleanor Schiff.

question: Will the hospital equipment be at the airport?
answer: Yes, everything they've got. How are the passengers doing?

question: I won't deceive you, Mister Striker. We're running out of time.
answer: Surely there must be something you can do.

question: I know what you're going to say, so save your breath.
answer: No. I haven't a thing to say. You've done the best you could. You really have. The best you could. I guess we can't expect to win 'em all. I want to tell you something I've kept to myself for years. I was in the war myself -- the Medical Corps. I was on duty late one night when a badly wounded pilot was brought in from a raid. He could barely talk, but he looked at me and he said, "Doc. The odds were against us up there but we went in anyway, and I'm glad we did. The captain made the right decision." The pilot's name was George Zipp.

question: George Zipp said that?
answer: And the last thing he said to me, "Doc," he said, "Sometime when the crew is up against it and the breaks are beating the boys, tell them to go out there with all they've got and win just one for the Zipper. I don't know where I'll be then, Doc," he said, "but I won't smell too good. That's for sure."

question: I know. I know. But it's his ship now, his command; he's in charge, he's the boss, the head man, the top dog, the big cheese, the head honcho... 'Passengers Certain to Die?!?!?!?!?!'
answer: There's a sale at Penny's!

question: All right, I'll need three men up in the tower. You, Neubauer. You, Macias.
answer: Me John. Big tree. Wagon train comes three, maybe four day away.

question: Stand by, Striker. I'm going to the tower. And good luck.
answer: The tower! Oh! Rapunzel! Rapunzel!

question: You are now eight miles from the airport. Turn right to a heading of zero eight niner, throttle back slightly and begin to lose altitude to fifteen hundred feet. Steve, I want every light you can get poured on that field.
answer: A truck is dumping a variety of lamps, fixtures, and light bulbs onto the runway.

question: Tower to all emergency vehicles. Runway is niner.
answer: Ambulances, fire trucks, and police cars start to move.

question: Civilian equipment, number three.
answer: Ambulances, firetrucks, and police cars speed toward runway. They are followed by a baggage truck, fuel truck, a taxi, Coke truck, an ice cream truck, farm machinery, and a cement mixer.

question: Thank you, Randy. You better leave sweetheart. You might get hurt in here.
answer: Ted...

question: Yes?
answer: I wanted you to know -- now -- I'm very proud.

question: Tell them the gear is down and we're ready to land.
answer: The gear is down.

question: Hold her steady, hold her steady!
answer: skidding.

question: Pull a lever!
answer: skidding. skidding.
